chapterTitle: Financial Statements, Taxes, and Cash Flow

columns.text: This exercise will explain the cash flow identity, the components of operating cash flow. We will also determine why interest paid is not a part of the latter.

**Cash flows** pertain to the amount of cash flowing in and out of business. Identifying an entity's cash sources would help analyze its liquidity and capacity to suffice daily operations, including the needs for borrowing transactions.

### 2.4a - Cash flow identity.

Cash flow identity is a formula used to understand an entity's cash transactions. Shown below is the procedure for such an equation.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Cash flow from assets} &= \text{Cash flow to creditors} + {\text{Cash flow to stockholders}}\\[1pt]
\end{aligned}$$

The cash receipts from an entity's assets must equal the cash paid to creditors and business owners.

### 2.4b - Components of operating cash flows.

The cash flows from assets consist of operating cash flows, capital spending, and change in net working capital. The operating cash flows refer to the net income of an entity, excluding non-cash items and interest expenses.

Shown below is the format of computing operating cash flows.

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Earnings before interest and taxes}&&\$\hspace{15pt}\text{XX}\\
\text{Add: Non-cash items}&&\text{xx}\\
\text{Less: Taxes}&&\underline{\hspace{25pt}\text{xx}}\\
\text{Operating cash flows}&&\underline{\underline{\$\hspace{15pt}\text{XX}}}\\
\end{array}$$

All non-cash items, such as **depreciation**, are excluded and added back in operating cash flows because they do not involve cash payments. On the other hand, we need to deduct **tax payments** since the entity needs to settle taxes in cash. If an entity does not pay the taxes incurred for the current period, we must exclude it from operating cash flows.

### 2.4c - Why is interest excluded in operating cash flows?

In contrast to accounting, finance excludes interest costs in computing operating cash flows. The primary reason is that interest paid is an expense incurred from financing activities and is unnecessary for running a business. An entity would not pay any interest should borrowing transactions did not occur.

The approach of computing cash flows is somehow different for accounting and finance. The former focuses on adhering to financial accounting standards, while the latter highlights financial and management considerations. Regardless, the bottom line is that an entity **must maintain enough cash** to suffice its operations and other business needs that may arise.
This exercise requires us to explain the why interest paid is not a component of operating cash flow.
Interest paid is  not a component of operating cash flow because it is considered a **financing cost**, not an operating expense.
